Posts.Title: Biopsy on Monday, and (of course) scared writesthings Ariom

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2014 09:19AM writesthings wrote: I had my biopsy on Monday and got the call a little earlier today.  I have invasive ductal carcinoma w/squamous differential.  Of course, by the time I got off the phone with the radiologist, the breast surgeon's office was closed, so I'll have to deal with that appointment tomorrow. I'm hanging in there, but I'm obviously not a happy camper at the moment.  Guess I'll be hanging out on the other boards soon...
Posts.Title: Biopsy on Monday, and (of course) scared writesthings Ariom

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2014 11:18PM writesthings wrote: nursiellp, I understand how you feel (as you know from my entry!).  Please don't blame yourself.  I've done that before when it came to medical tests (waiting a long time for an endometrial biopsy for what turned out to be just a polyp), and adding guilt on top of fear just made me feel worse.  If your friends are telling you that you shouldn't have let it go so long, I suppose you could just tell them, "I can't dwell on the past.  The important thing is that it's being looked at now."  As for Dr. Google, I've had to give up on him. :)  All the sonogram views I've seen online are for "classic" cases/examples of various breast conditions, and nothing looks exactly like my lump.  Mine has irregular borders but it's not spiculated, it seems to have appeared suddenly but it's wider than it is tall and has no internal blood flow, it's firm but it's moveable...heck, it could be anything.  That's what the biopsy will determine.  I'm scared of what the outcome will be, but I know I'd be more worried if I just let it go.  So I just step back from the computer and try to get on with my life.  It was very hard to do that at first, and if you're dealing with multiple lumps, I'm sure that's 10 times worse on the fear/worry factor.  But try to just get away from the computer, breathe, and focus on the here and now.  A friend of mine who had melanoma (successfully treated) said that when she was told her diagnosis, the doctor also told her, "The time you spend worrying will never be given back to you."  That, plus the support and encouragement of folks here, has helped me to deal with this period of waiting. But God, it's hard sometimes, I know.  I still have occasional crying episodes, or I wake up early in the morning and stare at the ceiling until I finally give up and get out of bed.  For right now, though, I'm trying to live my life as if everything's going to be okay - because no matter what the outcome, I don't want to look back on this time and think, "Why didn't I just enjoy myself?" Oh, and the falling down stuff - I've done that off and on for over a year!  In January I even fell and fractured a finger.  But I seriously doubt that anything like cancer is in either of our brains.  If cancer has spread to that point, I think we'd be a lot worse all the way around, not just in our boobs.  :) Hugs to you.  I'll be praying and hoping for all the best.  Keep us posted.
Posts.Title: Biopsy on Monday, and (of course) scared writesthings Ariom

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2014 12:11AM writesthings wrote: Thanks for sharing your experience and support, JoJoy.  Yeah, I wouldn't be surprised if this lump is something weird that ends up needing to be excised just to make sure, so I'm (semi-) prepared for that possibility, too.  I'll post an update when I know something one way or another. Thanks again, and I hope your surgery provides more definitive answers for you.
Posts.Title: Biopsy on Monday, and (of course) scared writesthings Ariom

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2014 01:41PM writesthings wrote: Thanks, Hortense.  I already have a notebook and folder started. And my husband has already taken the day off tomorrow and plans to be with me at my surgeon's appointment, whenever it turns out to be.  What a 25th anniversary present!
Posts.Title: Biopsy on Monday, and (of course) scared writesthings Ariom

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2014 06:23AM writesthings wrote: Thank you Mandy, Poppy, and Imheretoo.  After I sent the original message, I went out to lunch with a friend, and while we did talk for a bit about my week from hell, we had a good time and I really felt her support.  And then I came back home and found these messages waiting for me, and I just started crying from relief.  It's so good to hear from people who have gone through the same thing and who are involved in their own battles with cancer and yet who take the time to write thoughtful, helpful, and encouraging posts to me.  In my family growing up, we were always kind of discouraged from talking or showing emotions about this sort of thing - my parents were big on self-reliance - so it helps to be able to reach out and get support like this. I'm hoping, praying, and trusting that your own journeys will be successful ones.  I will try to stay away from Dr. Google (heh), breathe, and enjoy life and not worry until I have to.  And I will keep tabs on this topic/forum and let everyone know what happens.  Again, thank you.  (And if anyone else wants/needs to chime in, feel free!) :)
Posts.Title: Biopsy on Monday, and (of course) scared writesthings Ariom

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2014 09:53AM writesthings wrote: Thank you, keepthefaith and alexgram.  I appreciate the encouragement and words spoken from experience.  And yeah, on second thought, we probably ought to take that trip just to get away and have a chance to relax, no matter what the outcome.  So that's what we'll aim for. Thank you again, and hugs to you both.
Posts.Title: Biopsy on Monday, and (of course) scared writesthings Ariom

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2014 11:06AM writesthings wrote: Welcome to the club, nursiellip, LOL!  I had my first meeting with my surgeon last Friday, a chest x-ray Monday, a breast MRI tomorrow (Wednesday), and my next meeting with the surgeon this Friday, so I'll know more at that point what's going to happen when.  She hasn't talked about me meeting with an oncologist yet, although she did talk about seeing a plastic surgeon about reconstruction (although she gave me the option of waiting for a name until my next appointment).  At this point, my husband and I don't care whether reconstruction takes place or not - we want this fast-growing P.O.S. out of me!  I have smaller boobs, so it's not as big an issue for me if I get inflated there or not.  Okay, that sounds bad, LOL.  Anyway, from what I've read, oncologists seem not to get involved until after surgery unless they want you to have some treatment first to reduce the size of your tumor before surgery.  So what the surgeon says makes sense to me, although I defer to the experience of other women who've been through this before.  In any case, I'll be thinking about and praying for you.  Here's hoping we can get this stuff beat ASAP!
Posts.Title: Biopsy on Monday, and (of course) scared writesthings Ariom
